description: From Middle English ȝarken, ȝerken, from Old English ġearcian (“to prepare, make ready, procure, furnish, supply”), from Proto-Germanic *garwakōną (“to prepare”), from Proto-Indo-European *gʰrebʰ- (“to grab, take, rake”), equivalent to yare +‎ -k. Related to Old English ġearc (“ready, active, quick”), ġearu (“prepared, ready, equipped, complete, finished, yare”). More at yare.

verbs.description: yark (third-person singular simple present yarks, present participle yarking, simple past and past participle yarked)

entries.meaning: (transitive, UK dialectal) To make ready; prepare.
examples: [...] Yet thou hast given us leather to yark, and leather to bark, [...]

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To dispose; be set in order for; be destined or intended for.

description: Uncertain, probably originally imitative; compare jerk etc.

verbs.description: yark (third-person singular simple present yarks, present participle yarking, simple past and past participle yarked)

entries.meaning: To hit, strike, especially with a cane or whip.

examples: he would throw a Dagger, and make a whip to yarke and lash [tr. faisoit craqueter], as cunningly as any Carter in France.
